importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, marking the latest update on the UN’s call for improved global disaster alerts amid worsening extreme weather events.
The date when a mountain glacier in Switzerland was monitored and predicted to collapse, enabling evacuation of the village of Blatten, illustrating real-time early warning success.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The current year, during which extreme weather events globally have intensified, prompting urgent calls for better early-warning systems.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather, leaving millions—especially in developing nations—vulnerable.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of deaths in the past 50 years occurring in developing countries.
The WMO reports that over 2 million people have died due to weather, water, and climate-related hazards in the past 50 years.
While 108 countries now use some form of multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52), half still have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is particularly dire in fragile, conflict-affected regions.
Progress is being made in Africa, with more countries establishing functioning websites and standardized alert systems.
The WMO emphasizes that early warning leads to early action and aims to empower communities to respond proactively.
Recent extreme weather events in 2025—such as flooding in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US—highlight the urgency of improved monitoring.
The collapse of a Swiss glacier in May 2025, predicted through regular monitoring, led to the evacuation of Blatten, demonstrating the life-saving potential of early warning systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) is urging global action to close critical gaps in early-warning systems for extreme weather events, noting that nearly half of countries lack sufficient capacity, particularly in developing nations. The WMO highlights that over 2 million people have died due to weather and climate-related disasters in the past 50 years, with 90% of deaths occurring in vulnerable regions. While progress has been made—such as a rise in multi-hazard systems from 52 to 108 countries—many still have only basic or insufficient systems, especially in conflict-affected or fragile states. Recent disasters in 2025, including floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, underscore the urgent need for global monitoring. A real-world success story is the Swiss evacuation of Blatten in May 2025 due to predicted glacier collapse, demonstrating how early warning systems can save lives. The WMO stresses that early warnings lead to early action and aims to empower communities worldwide to respond proactively to climate change impacts.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
